name: Pesarattu (Green Moong Dal Dosa)
steps: Wash and soak green moong dal for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Drain water. Grind the soaked dal, ginger, green chilies, and cumin seeds with minimal water to a smooth batter. Add rice flour and salt; mix well.
Heat a tawa. Pour a ladleful of batter and spread it into a thin dosa. Sprinkle chopped onion on top if desired.
Drizzle oil around the edges and cook until golden brown and crisp.
Serve hot with ginger chutney (allam pachadi).
substitutions: Add a handful of finely chopped coriander leaves to the batter.
Serve with plain yogurt or sambar.

name: Gongura Pulihora (Sorrel Leaves Rice)
steps: Wash gongura leaves thoroughly. Sauté them with 2 green chilies in a little oil until they wilt and soften. Cool and grind to a coarse paste.
Heat peanut oil in a large pan. Add mustard seeds, urad dal, chana dal, and peanuts. Fry until dals are golden and peanuts are roasted.
Add remaining green chilies, curry leaves, and asafoetida. Sauté for a minute.
Add turmeric powder and the gongura paste. Cook for 5-7 minutes, stirring, until oil separates.
Add the cooled rice and salt. Mix gently but thoroughly, ensuring the rice is coated evenly with the paste.
Serve warm.
substitutions: For extra tanginess, add a small piece of tamarind while grinding the gongura.
Garnish with roasted cashews.

name: Gutti Vankaya Koora (Stuffed Brinjal Curry)
steps: Slit brinjals into a cross pattern from the bottom, keeping the stem intact. Soak in salted water to prevent discoloration.
Grind onion, ginger-garlic paste, red chili, coriander, cumin powders, peanut powder, sesame powder, and salt with a little water to a thick paste.
Stuff this paste generously into each brinjal. Keep any leftover paste aside.
Heat oil in a heavy-bottomed pan. Add mustard seeds and curry leaves. Once spluttering, carefully place the stuffed brinjals in the pan.
Cook covered on low heat, turning occasionally, until brinjals are partially cooked.
Add remaining paste, tamarind extract, and a cup of water. Cook covered until brinjals are fully tender and the gravy thickens.
Serve hot with rice or roti.
substitutions: Cashew powder can replace peanut powder for a richer texture.
Adjust spice levels as per preference.

name: Kakarakaya Fry (Bitter Gourd Stir-Fry)
steps: Wash bitter gourds, scrape off bumps (optional), slice thinly, and remove seeds. Mix with salt and turmeric, let sit for 20 mins. Squeeze out bitter juice.
Heat oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds, cumin seeds, and curry leaves. Let them splutter.
Add chopped onion and green chilies. Sauté until onion is translucent.
Add the squeezed bitter gourd slices. Fry on medium heat, stirring occasionally, until they are crisp and golden brown.
Add red chili powder, coriander powder, and peanut powder. Mix well and fry for another 5 minutes.
Serve hot with rice or roti.
substitutions: To reduce bitterness further, blanch the bitter gourd slices before frying.
Add a pinch of jaggery at the end to balance the flavors.

name: Ulava Charu (Horse Gram Soup/Rasam)
steps: Wash and soak horse gram overnight. Pressure cook with 4 cups water until very soft (about 8-10 whistles). Strain the liquid (this is the Ulava Charu base) and keep the cooked dal aside for another dish.
Soak tamarind in warm water, extract pulp.
Dry roast cumin seeds, coriander seeds, and dry red chilies. Grind with green chilies and half the garlic cloves to a fine paste.
In a pot, combine the Ulava Charu base, tamarind pulp, ground spice paste, and salt. Bring to a boil and simmer for 30-45 minutes, allowing flavors to deepen.
For tempering: Heat oil. Add mustard seeds, remaining crushed garlic, and curry leaves. Let them splutter.
Pour the tempering into the simmering Ulava Charu. Stir and serve hot with plain rice and a dollop of ghee.
substitutions: Can be made thicker by adding a little cornflour slurry at the end.
A pinch of jaggery can be added for a hint of sweetness.

name: Boorelu (Sweet Lentil Dumplings)
steps: Wash and soak urad dal and rice for 4 hours. Grind to a smooth, thick batter with a pinch of salt. Set aside.
Wash and cook chana dal until soft but not mushy. Drain excess water.

In a pan, combine cooked chana dal, grated jaggery, and cardamom powder. Cook on low heat, stirring continuously, until jaggery melts and the mixture thickens into a firm dough-like consistency. Let it cool.
Make small lemon-sized balls from the chana dal-jaggery mixture.
Dip each ball in the urad dal-rice batter, ensuring it's fully coated.
Deep fry in hot oil until golden brown and crispy.
Serve warm.
substitutions: For a healthier version, shallow fry or bake after brushing with ghee (though texture will differ).
Add a pinch of nutmeg powder to the filling.

name: Mirchi Bajji (Chilli Fritters)
steps: Wash green chilies, slit them lengthwise, and remove seeds (optional, for less spice).
In a bowl, combine besan, rice flour, baking soda, red chili powder, ajwain, and salt. Add water gradually to make a thick, smooth batter.
Heat oil for deep frying.
Dip each green chili in the batter, ensuring it's fully coated. Carefully drop into hot oil.
Deep fry until golden brown and crispy. Remove with a slotted spoon and drain excess oil.
Serve hot with a sprinkle of chaat masala or finely chopped onion-coriander filling.
substitutions: For a healthier version, air fry or shallow fry with minimal oil (texture will vary).
Add a pinch of ginger-garlic paste to the batter for extra flavor.

name: Pesarapappu Charu (Moong Dal Rasam)
steps: Wash moong dal and pressure cook with 1.5 cups water and turmeric until soft. Mash well.
In a pot, combine mashed dal, tamarind extract, slit green chilies, and 1.5 cups water. Bring to a boil and simmer for 10 minutes.
Meanwhile, crush garlic and cumin seeds together.
For tempering: Heat oil. Add mustard seeds, crushed garlic-cumin, curry leaves, and asafoetida. Let them splutter.
Add tempering to the simmering dal mixture. Season with salt. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves and serve hot.
substitutions: Can add a small chopped tomato while simmering for extra flavor.
Adjust spice levels by varying green chilies.

name: Medu Vada (Savory Lentil Doughnuts)
steps: Wash and soak urad dal for at least 3 hours. Drain completely.
Grind the dal with minimal water to a very smooth, thick, and fluffy batter. Add salt and mix well.
Add chopped onion, green chilies, grated ginger, curry leaves, and crushed peppercorns to the batter. Mix gently.
Heat oil for deep frying. Wet your hands, take a small portion of batter, make a ball, flatten it, and make a hole in the center.
Carefully drop the vada into hot oil. Fry until golden brown and crispy.
Serve hot with sambar and coconut chutney.
substitutions: For healthier option, air fry or shallow fry after brushing with oil.
Add a pinch of baking soda for extra crispness (optional).

name: Upma (Savory Semolina Porridge)
steps: Dry roast semolina in a pan until lightly golden and aromatic. Set aside.
Heat oil in the same pan. Add mustard seeds, urad dal, and chana dal. Fry until dals turn golden.
Add chopped onion, green chilies, grated ginger, and curry leaves. Sauté until onion is translucent.
Add chopped carrots and peas. Sauté for 2-3 minutes.
Pour in water and bring to a rolling boil. Add salt.
Gradually add the roasted semolina, stirring continuously to prevent lumps. Cook, stirring occasionally, until water is absorbed and upma is cooked through.
Serve hot with pickle or chutney.
substitutions: Add roasted peanuts or cashews for extra crunch.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.

name: Chintapandu Pulihora (Tamarind Rice)
steps: Soak tamarind in warm water for 15 minutes and extract thick pulp.
Heat peanut oil in a large pan. Add mustard seeds. Once spluttering, add urad dal, chana dal, peanuts, and dry red chilies. Fry until dals are golden and peanuts are roasted.
Add green chilies, curry leaves, and asafoetida. Sauté for a minute.
Add turmeric powder and the tamarind pulp. Cook on medium heat, stirring, until the mixture thickens and oil separates from the edges.
Add the cooled rice and salt. Mix gently but thoroughly, ensuring the rice is coated evenly with the pulihora paste.
Serve warm.
substitutions: Add a pinch of jaggery to balance the tanginess of tamarind.
Garnish with roasted cashews for richness.

name: Poornam Boorelu (Sweet Festival Fritters)
steps: Wash and soak urad dal and rice for 4 hours. Grind to a smooth, thick batter with a pinch of salt. Set aside.
Wash and cook chana dal until soft but not mushy. Drain excess water.

In a pan, combine cooked chana dal, grated jaggery, and cardamom powder. Cook on low heat, stirring continuously, until jaggery melts and the mixture thickens into a firm dough-like consistency. Let it cool.
Make small lemon-sized balls from the chana dal-jaggery mixture (poornam).
Dip each poornam ball in the urad dal-rice batter, ensuring it's fully coated. Carefully drop into hot oil.
Deep fry until golden brown and crispy.
Serve warm.
substitutions: For a healthier version, shallow fry or bake after brushing with ghee (though texture will differ).
Add a pinch of nutmeg powder to the filling.

name: Modak/Kozhukattai (Steamed Sweet Dumplings)
steps: For the outer cover: Bring water, salt, and sesame oil to a boil. Reduce heat, add rice flour, and stir vigorously to form a dough. Cover and let it cool slightly.
For the filling (poornam): In a pan, combine grated jaggery, grated coconut, and cardamom powder. Cook on low heat, stirring, until jaggery melts and mixture thickens. Let it cool.
Knead the rice flour dough until smooth. Take small portions, flatten into a disc, and place a spoonful of filling in the center.
Bring the edges together and seal to form a dumpling (or use a modak mold).
Steam the kozhukattai for 8-10 minutes until cooked and shiny.
Serve warm.
substitutions: Sweetened condensed milk can be used in the filling for a richer taste.
Savory kozhukattai can be made with a vegetable filling.
